\makeatletter

  \let\origtableofcontents=\tableofcontents
  \def\tableofcontents{\@ifnextchar[{\origtableofcontents}{\gobbletableofcontents}}
  \def\gobbletableofcontents#1{\origtableofcontents}
}

\usepackage{xcolor}

\beamertemplatenavigationsymbolsempty
\setbeamercovered{transparent}

\definecolor{green}{RGB}{0,164,0}

\makeatother

\begin{document}
\begin{frame}{Example problem - infinite number of solutions}

Solve the system of equations:

\vspace{-1em}

\begin{alignat*}{4}
4x_{1} & \;+\; & x_{2} & \;-\; & 2x_{3} & \;=\; &  & 7\\
3x_{1} & \;-\; & 4x_{2} & \;+\; & 8x_{3} & \;=\; & - & 9\\
x_{1} & \;+\; & 2x_{2} & \;-\; & 4x_{3} & \;=\; &  & 7
\end{alignat*}

The process can be summarized as:

\[
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
4 & 1 & -2 & 7\\
3 & -4 & 8 & -9\\
1 & 2 & -4 & 7
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{\text{Row operations}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 0 & 0 & 1\\
0 & 1 & -2 & 3\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\]

\end{frame}
%
\begin{frame}{}

For convenience, swap rows 1 and 3 to perform next operations with
integers instead of fractions.

{\small{}
\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{blue}4} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}7}\\
3 & -4 & 8 & -9\\
{\color{red}1} & {\color{red}2} & {\color{red}-4} & {\color{red}7}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{{\color{blue}R_{1}}\leftrightarrow{\color{red}R_{3}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{red}1} & {\color{red}2} & {\color{red}-4} & {\color{red}7}\\
3 & -4 & 8 & -9\\
{\color{blue}4} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}7}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}
}{\small\par}

Make $a_{21}=0$ using information from the first row.

{\small{}
\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}2} & {\color{blue}-4} & {\color{blue}7}\\
{\color{red}3} & {\color{red}-4} & {\color{red}8} & {\color{red}-9}\\
4 & 1 & -2 & 7
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{-3{\color{blue}R_{1}}+{\color{red}R_{2}}\to{\color{green}R_{2}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}2} & {\color{blue}-4} & {\color{blue}7}\\
{\color{green}0} & {\color{green}-10} & {\color{green}20} & {\color{green}-30}\\
4 & 1 & -2 & 7
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}
}{\small\par}

Make $a_{31}=0$ using information from the first row.

{\small{}
\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}2} & {\color{blue}-4} & {\color{blue}7}\\
0 & -10 & 20 & -30\\
{\color{red}4} & {\color{red}1} & {\color{red}-2} & {\color{red}7}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{-4{\color{blue}R_{1}}+{\color{red}R_{3}}\to{\color{green}R_{3}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}2} & {\color{blue}-4} & {\color{blue}7}\\
0 & -10 & 20 & -30\\
{\color{green}0} & {\color{green}-7} & {\color{green}14} & {\color{green}-21}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}
}{\small\par}
\end{frame}
%
\begin{frame}{}

For convenience, divide the second row by $-10$ to perform next operations
with integers instead of fractions.

\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 2 & -4 & 7\\
{\color{red}0} & {\color{red}-10} & {\color{red}20} & {\color{red}-30}\\
0 & -7 & 14 & -21
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{-\nicefrac{1}{10}{\color{red}R_{2}}\to{\color{green}R_{2}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 2 & -4 & 7\\
{\color{green}0} & {\color{green}1} & {\color{green}-2} & {\color{green}3}\\
0 & -7 & 14 & -21
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}

Make $a_{32}=0$ using information from the second row.

\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 2 & -4 & 7\\
{\color{blue}0} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}3}\\
{\color{red}0} & {\color{red}-7} & {\color{red}14} & {\color{red}-21}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{7{\color{blue}R_{2}}+{\color{red}R_{3}}\to{\color{green}R_{3}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 2 & -4 & 7\\
{\color{blue}0} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}3}\\
{\color{green}0} & {\color{green}0} & {\color{green}0} & {\color{green}0}
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}

\end{frame}
%
\begin{frame}{}

\[
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
1 & 2 & -4 & 7\\
0 & 1 & -2 & 3\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\]

\medskip{}

The matrix is now in upper triangular form. Hence the unknown values
can be determined using back substitution.
\begin{enumerate}[a.]
\item Starting from row 3, $x_{3}=t$, where $t$ is an arbitrary constant.
\item Using $x_{3}=t$ in row 2, $x_{2}=3+2x_{3}=3+2t$.
\item Using $x_{3}=t$ and $x_{2}=3+2t$ in row 1, $x_{1}=7-2x_{2}+4x_{3}=7-6-4t+4t=1$.
\end{enumerate}
\medskip{}

Alternately, using Gauss-Jordan elimination, the left-hand side matrix
can be reduced to an identity matrix from which the solution can be
determined by inspection.
\end{frame}
%
\begin{frame}{}

Make $a_{12}=0$ using information from the second row.

\begin{equation}
\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{red}1} & {\color{red}2} & {\color{red}-4} & {\color{red}7}\\
{\color{blue}0} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}3}\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}\stackrel{{\color{blue}-2R_{2}}+{\color{red}R_{1}}\to{\color{green}R_{1}}}{\Longrightarrow}\begin{bmatrix}\begin{array}{rrr|r}
{\color{green}1} & {\color{green}0} & {\color{green}0} & {\color{green}1}\\
{\color{blue}0} & {\color{blue}1} & {\color{blue}-2} & {\color{blue}3}\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\end{bmatrix}
\end{equation}
\end{frame}

\end{document}
